text: hi everyone anthony fantano here
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review charlie hayden and
hank jones come sunday charlie hayden
and hank jones are two very well
traveled jazz musicians charlie hayden
is a bass player and has been a
trailblazer in avant-garde experimental
and free jazz for years over the course
of hayden's career he's released a lot
of albums collaborated with greats like
alice coltrane and pat matheny and
ornette coleman as well and his partner
on this album hank jones is a jazz piano
player and he's collaborated with many
greats himself and has a pretty hefty
discography too sadly he passed away in
2010 i don't know how much more recorded
material there is out there of him
that's yet to be released that would
still sound fresh and interest his fan
base so
i don't know this this might be the last
new recording with his piano playing on
it to to come out this album comes
sunday it's charlie hayden on upright
bass hank jones on piano
just
reinventing all of these spirituals
gospel songs and hymns
and traditional songs folk songs as well
you know i i never really bring it up
but i've always kind of had a real sweet
spot for this kind of music i actually
even
subscribe to a youtube channel called
strolling down memory lane that throws
up that kind of music all the time
there's just a really sweet gentle and
warm
aura around this kind of music this kind
of music is the building block for
a lot of american music it's the roots
it's the blueprint to all the jazz that
charlie hayden and hank jones played
throughout their career and this kind of
music was a huge inspiration to tons of
singer song writers especially one of my
favorites tom waits now this is not the
first time
that charlie hayden and hank jones have
collaborated on a project like this they
actually released an album a professor
of mine turned me on to in college that
was put out in 1995 called steal away
where they're pretty much going in the
same direction just reinventing
reinterpreting tunes from that same
style from that same traditional music
era
if you've ever wanted to listen to music
that just felt like it had
lots of
dignity
dignity
then this is definitely a must listen
even though come sunday was recorded
around 15 years after steal away was the
intent of
what hayden and jones want to do with
these songs has remained roughly the
same they just perform them together
just very softly very quietly but also
very intently they don't just let these
songs breeze by you know for the most
part they kind of try to leave their
fingerprints on these versions and the
way that they play these songs out with
this very solemn this very kind of clean
performance it's really like kind of
going to an old country church and just
everything is very
you know
rootsy and rural but also very beautiful
and charming now even though i really
like steel away i am
liking come sunday too but i do feel
like i'm a little on the fence with it
as well and it's mostly because of
similarities it has and doesn't have
with steel away on steel away you just
got one reinterpretation after another
of these old standbys that
were quiet but very passionately played
and the tone of the instruments was
really nice too the bass was soft but
very punchy very kind of
had some thickness to it and the piano
though it was quiet it had these very
light lush rushes of sound sometimes too
and hank jones displayed a lot of very
nimble playing when win win but the one
thing this album doesn't do as much as
steal away is
embellish these songs i don't know if it
was because they were recording this
project years and years later or if they
really wanted to
simplify their approach to these songs
they really kind of wanted the songs to
stand on their own and kind of not
distract from that with the flashy
playing or something but there are some
tracks on here like down by the
riverside or blessed assurance where
hank and
charlie just really are playing it
straight sure there are some solos on
that track but there are also moments
like god rest ye merry gentlemen where
it seems like they'll go through the
entire track and play it so plainly and
so rigidly that i i really start getting
kind of bored with it i'm not really
looking for these tracks to be really
jazzed up an upbeat or anything like
that i mean i think there are some songs
on here that benefit from the quiet
volume of this album like the opening
track take my hand precious lord which
is just played so slowly and so softly
that it just reaches new levels of
beauty for me and those are the spots
that really hit me on this album the
heaviest there are songs on here like
give me that old-time religion where it
does feel more upbeat it is performed
pretty well it is embellished really
nicely you've got those spots like i
said that are so soft filled with
dignity filled with beauty and then
again you've got this other side to this
album that feels so straightforward so
unchanged that i could almost hear any
two musicians playing it this way you
know which is a bit of a shame because
yeah i am here to listen to the tunes
because the tunes are beautiful the
tunes are gorgeous the tunes are well
traveled the tunes here have withstood
the test of time but i'm also here to
listen to hank and charlie and i think i
would have enjoyed this record a little
bit more if i felt like they were more
in balance with some of these songs like
they weren't sort of letting the songs
overshadow them at some points still i
think this is a pretty good album at
least worth a couple listens through and
try to give the album that came out
before this one a chance as well i'm
feeling a strong six to a light seven on
this just a lot of songs on here that
didn't feel explored enough some songs
because they weren't all that explored
ended up being pretty short but if any
of you have listened to this
and if you have let me know what do you
think of this thing do you love it
do you hate it
why
how could you hate it anthony fantano
charlie hayden and hank jones come
sunday
what should i review next
forever
